assessments.status_rationale: Today’s news bullets contain no report of Nvidia announcing (or being reliably reported to have signed) a definitive agreement to acquire Groq for ≥$10B. No relevant M&A confirmation or transaction value is cited.
No bullet references BP, Castrol, Stonepeak, or completion/closing of a stake sale. There is no evidence to mark the prediction correct or incorrect at this time.

None of the listed stories indicate Harvard has filed a federal lawsuit against the U.S. executive branch or a federal agency related to the described dispute. No court filing or announcement is referenced.
The news bullets provide no indication that the DOJ Office of Inspector General has announced a review/investigation into handling/redaction/release of Epstein-related document disclosures.

No item mentions Amazon launching a broadly available U.S. AI shopping agent that can autonomously complete multi-step shopping tasks and checkout. AI-related bullets are general market commentary, not a product launch.
There is no report in today’s bullets of a large U.S. investor-owned utility announcing a ≥24-month coal retirement delay explicitly citing new/expected federal policy support for coal retention.
None of the bullets refer to a U.S.-Honduras bilateral migration/security cooperation package totaling ≥$100M. The prominent U.S. foreign-policy item relates to U.S. military action in Nigeria.

While there are articles about the U.S.-Ukraine peace plan and Russia’s likely reaction, the bullets do not confirm any direct in-person meeting between Ukrainian and Russian official delegations that explicitly includes discussion of a demilitarized zone and/or troop pullbacks in eastern Ukraine.
No bullet reports that Elsevier, Springer Nature, Wiley, Taylor & Francis, or IEEE has announced a mandatory AI-use disclosure requirement embedded in manuscript submission across all journals.
